Some state legislators want to:

- end 24/7 drop boxes for ballot returns
- limit vote by mail options during a pandemic
- end automatic voter registration when obtaining a license

This is wrong. We must expand access to the ballot box, not make it harder to vote. https://twitter.com/ledgerenquirer/status/1357336839317819392 QT @LedgerEnquirer There are over 20 bills in the legislature right now related to voting. When the pandemic hit, Chief Justice Beasley was at the forefront by appointing a COVID-19 task force to keep the courts and our people safe. I’m proud of all the work she has done to promote racial equality and to make North Carolina a more just place.
Chief Justice Beasley became the first African American woman to be chief justice in March 2019 and she served on the state’s highest court since 2012.
For #BlackHistoryMonth, I’m proud to honor my good friend, former @JusticeCBeasley for her contributions to North Carolina and the law.

It is shameful that Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy will not hold Congresswoman Greene accountable and will not demand greater accountability from his caucus at large, especially after the violence we all experienced on January 6.

Congresswoman Greene has repeatedly expressed her support for assassinating elected leaders and has spread harmful conspiracy theories that denigrate the victims of 9/11, the Sandy Hook and Parkland school shootings, and the California wildfires.

I fully supported the action to remove Congresswoman Greene from her committee assignments and believe that she should also be censured and resign from Congress immediately. There must be strong and swift accountability for those who incite and promote political violence.

This has been the law since 1935 and it is so heartening to hear @POTUS lend his voice to this important concept.  NOW is the time for us to step up for U.S. workers and restore these fundamental rights. 
We must #PassthePROAct and we must do it fast.

“It is hereby declared to be the policy of the United States to…encourag[e] the practice and procedure of collective bargaining and by protecting the exercise by workers of full freedom of association, self-organization, and designation of representatives of their own choosing”

As a result, economic inequality has soared. Strong unions helped reduce poverty & build the middle class. The subsequent degradation of union rights has helped shrink it. The #PROAct would do so much to reverse these trends—including the scourge of racial & gender inequality.

The fact is that way too many business interests are afraid of workers’ collective power to demand higher wages, better benefits & safer working conditions. That’s why they engage in coercive, often illegal, union busting campaigns & spend $340M/year on union busting consultants.

The sad reality is that over the past 86 years, not one provision; not one word; not one comma has been added to the law to advance private sector workers’ freedom to form unions & bargain collectively. Instead we’ve had 86 long years of the systematic erosion of workers’ rights.

Today I helped lead over two hundred colleagues in the House and Senate in reintroducing the #PROAct. https://twitter.com/EdLaborCmte/status/1357396515657031682 QT @EdLaborCmte Today, top @HouseDemocrats & @SenateDems introduced the #PROAct, a bold proposal that protects and strengthens the basic right of American workers to stand together and negotiate for higher wages, better benefits, and safer working conditions.

Douglass’ mere presence put him at risk because he was (at this time) an escaped slave, not a freed man. Being caught could lead to severe physical punishment and a return to slavery, or death by lynch mob. In 1895, Douglass returned to West Chester to speak once again. /4

Also present was Dr. Edwin Fussell, founder of the Women’s Medical College of Philadelphia and son of Dr. Bartholomew Fussell, a Chester County native who was one of the greatest conductors of the Underground Railroad, aiding over 200 slaves to freedom. /3

Barred from hotel accommodations because he was Black, Douglass was housed by two Quaker sisters who ran a nearby school. At the meeting, he joined fellow abolitionist James Fulton Jr., founder of the East Fallowfield Township Anti-Slavery society. /2

As we continue to celebrate #BlackHistoryMonth and its roots in our own community, I'd like to honor the moment in time when known poet and abolitionist, Frederick Douglass, came to West Chester in June of 1844 for an anti-slavery meeting to sway public opinion. /1

Lena O. Smith fought against racial discrimination through her work as a lawyer in mid-20th-century Minnesota. She was the first black female lawyer in the state and went on to become the first female president of the NAACP Minneapolis chapter. Lena persevered like no other.

Toni Stone grew up in St. Paul, Minnesota where she would play baseball with the boys in her neighborhood. Although her love of baseball was considered “unladylike”, Toni went on to become the first woman to play as a regular on an American professional baseball team.

Nellie Stone Johnson, a civil rights activist and organizer, was the first black elected official in Minneapolis. She was instrumental in the creation of the Fair Employment Practices Dept., which was the first of its kind in the US. Nellie was a champion of working people.

American industry would not be what it is today without the advances in chemistry that helped us make strides along the way. 

I look forward to working with my colleagues to continue to educate and advocate for the critical role that chemistry plays in the American economy.

.@MartyJWalsh would bring an important perspective to @USDOL as the first union leader to head it in decades. He also brings a long track record as a collaborative leader & the right experience, leadership, & priorities to protect workers during this critical moment.

That is why I will be reintroducing the bipartisan and vastly popular #LymphedemaTreatmentAct that will require Medicare to cover compression garment treatment. Cancer is bad enough. Survivors shouldn’t have to worry about insurance coverage for essential post-cancer treatment.

Lymphedema is a painful disease that can be caused by cancer treatment and affects over 15% of cancer survivors. Sadly, compression garments, which are essential to best practice Lymphedema treatment, are not covered by Medicare.

On World Cancer Day, we remember those lost to this tragic disease, those battling it currently, and those who have survived. We must continue to fund research for cures. We must also work to better help survivors struggling with the long-term effects of treatment.
Today we stand in solidarity with those suffering from cancer and with their family and loved ones supporting them.  #IAmAndIWill #WorldCancerDay

I also asked the panel how Congress can re-instill confidence in the safety of public transportation as long as we all follow public health guidelines.
